AutomatedPrinterDialog_82.speaker: Narrator
AutomatedPrinterDialog_82.text: *Your attention is drawn to a metal block loaded into a slot labelled 'Headline Article'.*

AutomatedPrinterDialog_57.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_57.text: Check the headline currently in the printer.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_80.speaker: Narrator
AutomatedPrinterDialog_80.text: *The Mouth's next edition appears to be led by a piece commemorating the late Lord Gortash.*

AutomatedPrinterDialog_68.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_68.text: Load another headline in to the printer.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_6.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_6.text: Force the printing press open and clear the loaded headline.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_106.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_106.text: Reach inside and carefully remove the loaded headline.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_39.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_39.text: Dislodge the current headline with a precise flick of the wrist.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_44.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_44.text: Wrench the printing press open and rip out the loaded headline.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_40.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_40.text: Ohoho... You've returned. Ready to sow some discord?

AutomatedPrinterDialog_61.speaker: Narrator
AutomatedPrinterDialog_61.text: *The smell of hot ink and whirr of machinery fills your senses as you approach the Baldur's Mouth printworks.*
AutomatedPrinterDialog_61.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player walks towards the imposing printer, rumbling away. - REUSE ANIMATION FROM N45

AutomatedPrinterDialog_71.speaker: Narrator
AutomatedPrinterDialog_71.text: *The printing press whirrs furiously - hopefully Gortash's death will take your spot in the headlines.*

AutomatedPrinterDialog_86.speaker: Narrator
AutomatedPrinterDialog_86.text: *As you get closer to the printworks, something odd happens. You hear it speak.*
AutomatedPrinterDialog_86.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player walks towards the imposing printer, rumbling away.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_89.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_89.text: Oi, gormless - not one step further! You are interrupting art.
AutomatedPrinterDialog_89.context: NodeContext: the printer whispers this to itself

AutomatedPrinterDialog_154.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_154.text: Sorry to disturb you, but I need to change the next edition's headline.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_113.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_113.text: My art! I'm an artiste. Name's Jelliwig.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_47.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_47.text: I need to change an article in the next edition.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_85.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_85.text: Are you addled in the head? I am no chattering contraption, I am a person. An artist. Name's Jelliwig.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_133.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_133.text: This is my paintbrush. I make sure everything that's in those big ugly article blocks becomes fine printed artistry. I'm a master pensman, I am.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_153.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_153.text: Dolly can't stop talking about you. Hero this, hero that, hero here, hero there. Hello, hero.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_17.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_17.text: You know, there's some absolute filth about you in tomorrow's edition. Seeing as you were kind enough to free Dolly, how's about I do you a favour?

AutomatedPrinterDialog_145.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_145.text: Why don't we change the headline? We can load up something a bit less... damaging for your reputation?

AutomatedPrinterDialog_64.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_64.text: Well, first, I've got to release the old, nasty top story. Oooh, there. Now, you've got to find a new article to replace it.
AutomatedPrinterDialog_64.context: CinematicNodeContext: there's a rumble as the articles are loosened, and a thunk on "there."

AutomatedPrinterDialog_27.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_27.text: I don't want to meddle with the paper.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_50.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_50.text: BORING. You deserve exactly what Ettvard prints about you - I might even add a footnote about you having the clap.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_16.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_16.text: Now scram it. One mistake and the reputation of Baldur's Mouth Gazette crumbles to dust.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_72.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_72.text: There's an article about me in the next edition - I need to stop it printing.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_77.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_77.text: Oho... really? There was that rather defamatory headline... Yes, I see the resemblance.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_20.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_20.text: Think you're clever? It takes a lot of craft to write trash this good.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_126.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_126.text: Where's your gazette's Golden Quill Award for Truth and Excellence? Don't have one? Bloody thought not.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_76.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_76.text: I'd love to see an example of your work.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_45.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_45.text: I'm actually a great admirer of your work - may I see?

AutomatedPrinterDialog_118.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_118.text: Ahah, someone who appreciates the art of words. And a celebrity to boot. You'll enjoy this.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_49.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_49.text: As it happens, the next edition has an article about you. Ooh, it's a mean one, too - real nasty. Ettvard must really have it out for you. Hard luck.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_7.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_7.text: Will require a delicate touch to spruce up. Think I'll need my number seven pen. Real sharp.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_74.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_74.text: You need to stop it from being printed.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_28.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_28.text: I'm afraid I can't help you. I've got a good thing going here - letting you swap out a whole article might get Ettvard suspicious.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_124.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_124.text: Maybe you could do me a favour and stop the presses? Change the article?

AutomatedPrinterDialog_18.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_18.text: What does Ettvard have against me?

AutomatedPrinterDialog_136.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_136.text: I wouldn't take it too personal. Ettvard gets his lines from up top, then gets all worked up over it.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_0.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_0.text: Although, it not being personal doesn't change how shafted you'll be.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_9.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_9.text: Then get out my way. I need to clear my reputation.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_131.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_131.text: Help me change the article or I'll banish you from the printer.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_48.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_48.text: Now, I'm not sure you could get me out of here, but I'm not taking any bloody chances.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_141.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_141.text: Right. Let's get this article nice and loose... There. You'll need to find a replacement piece, of course. Make sure it's a good one.
AutomatedPrinterDialog_141.context: CinematicNodeContext: there's a rumble as the articles are loosened, and a thunk on "there."

AutomatedPrinterDialog_32.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_32.text: Where can I find the stuff to print a new broadsheet?

AutomatedPrinterDialog_100.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_100.text: Listen, mate. I'm already doing you a favour. I'm sure you can figure it out yourself.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_120.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_120.text: As the old saying goes: 'Ours is not to wonder why, ours is but to print or die.' Or something like that.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_55.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_55.text: I have an article. Let's get started.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_129.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_129.text: I'll get on with finding an article.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_59.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_59.text: You lie worse than Ettvard spells. If you care so much, change them yourself. I have work to do.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_26.speaker: Narrator
AutomatedPrinterDialog_26.text: *There is a brief, disgruntled huff, then no more noises from the fey creature. It seems you are on your own.*

AutomatedPrinterDialog_36.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_36.text: Force the printing press open and clear the loaded headline.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_148.speaker: Narrator
AutomatedPrinterDialog_148.text: *You manage to clear the printer's load. It is ready for a new headline.*

AutomatedPrinterDialog_29.speaker: Narrator
AutomatedPrinterDialog_29.text: *You fumble unsuccessfully with the printer and hear a loud thud. The machine leaps into life, printing whatever was already inside.*

AutomatedPrinterDialog_60.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_60.text: Reach inside and carefully remove the loaded headline.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_38.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_38.text: Reach inside and carefully remove the loaded headline.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_142.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_142.text: Wrench the printing press open and rip out the loaded headline.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_110.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_110.text: It'll suck to be you tomorrow, mate.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_11.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_11.text: Wouldn't changing the article be delightfully naughty?

AutomatedPrinterDialog_139.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_139.text: You would twist my love of mischief-making for your own perverse needs? Despicable.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_73.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_73.text: A-ha! A meddler after my own heart - wonderful.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_102.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_102.text: Do it, you stupid creature. Unless you want to be ripped apart, piece by piece?

AutomatedPrinterDialog_53.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_53.text: All right, all right! No need for violence.
AutomatedPrinterDialog_53.context: NodeContext: offended and a little huffy

AutomatedPrinterDialog_156.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_156.text: Do it, or I'll melt you into a steaming puddle of iron and regret.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_23.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_23.text: Too bad Ettvard will never get to enjoy it - I killed him.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_63.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_63.text: I agree. The right words at the right time - literal magic. We're alike, you and I.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_1.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_1.text: FINE! Have it your way! No appreciation of art, these bloody arm-havers.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_155.speaker: Narrator
AutomatedPrinterDialog_155.text: *You feel a dancing, mischievous magic sparking through air around the printer. A fey creature resides within.*

AutomatedPrinterDialog_52.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_52.text: A talking printer? Fey magic never ceases to amaze.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_31.speaker: Narrator
AutomatedPrinterDialog_31.text: *A familiar magic dances around the printer, reminiscent of your own hag-touched eye. A fey creature resides within the machine.*

AutomatedPrinterDialog_96.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_96.text: Paper's printing right now, pal. Should be on the streets tomorrow.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_97.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_97.text: I may not like you, but I loved the look Ettvard had on his face when he saw the broadsheet. Well played, mortal.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_107.speaker: Narrator
AutomatedPrinterDialog_107.text: *You approach the printer, noting its ink splots and intricate cogs. Before you can get closer, however, it begins to speak.*
AutomatedPrinterDialog_107.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player walks towards the imposing printer, rumbling away.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_130.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_130.text: Oi! Gormless! Over here. Thought I recognised you. Dolly Dolly Dolly was right - you aren't much of a looker.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_116.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_116.text: We both love cheeky words. She does all the shouting, I do the writing.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_75.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_75.text: Am I going mad or are you a talking printer?

AutomatedPrinterDialog_146.speaker: Player
AutomatedPrinterDialog_146.text: Let me guess - another fey who needs freeing?

AutomatedPrinterDialog_10.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_10.text: I'm not trapped, you fool. This printing machine is just marvellous. We've nothing like it in the Feywild.

AutomatedPrinterDialog_111.speaker: Narrator
AutomatedPrinterDialog_111.text: *The printing press is running at full tilt. You don't see any way to interfere with it now without losing several fingers.*

AutomatedPrinterDialog_115.speaker: Narrator
AutomatedPrinterDialog_115.text: *The printer whirrs, ready to print an edition with the currently loaded headline.*
AutomatedPrinterDialog_115.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player walks towards the imposing printer, rumbling away. - REUSE ANIMATION FROM N45

AutomatedPrinterDialog_125.speaker: Narrator
AutomatedPrinterDialog_125.text: *The machine whirrs noisily as your broadsheet prints.*

AutomatedPrinterDialog_134.speaker: Printing Press
AutomatedPrinterDialog_134.text: Ohohoho... Ettvard was fuming this morn... What a grand jape. It's best we lie low for a while, though - don't want him figuring us out.

Wanderer_03_0.speaker: Reagan Splint
Wanderer_03_0.text: Still can't fathom that they hang folk in this city - those gallows get more use than some temples.

Wanderer_03_10.speaker: Reagan Splint
Wanderer_03_10.text: Every tenday I write into the Baldur's Mouth about it, and every edition fails to mention it. Pathetic.

Wanderer_03_1.speaker: Reagan Splint
Wanderer_03_1.text: Normal folk die every day on these gallows, and there's naught about it in the broadsheet. But one lord dies and it's all they bloody talk about!

Wanderer_03_2.speaker: Reagan Splint
Wanderer_03_2.text: I hope the gazette is right about you. This city is in desperate need of good folk.

Wanderer_03_3.speaker: Reagan Splint
Wanderer_03_3.text: If people were publicly hanged in a proper city - Neverwinter, say - it'd be all over the broadsheets. A disgrace.

Wanderer_03_4.speaker: Reagan Splint
Wanderer_03_4.text: I read about you in the Baldur's Mouth. Surprised they haven't got you on the gallows already.

Wanderer_03_5.speaker: Reagan Splint
Wanderer_03_5.text: You read about Gortash dying? The gazette's speculating foul play.

Wanderer_03_9.speaker: Reagan Splint
Wanderer_03_9.text: If that's true, bet they have the folk that did it in these gallows soon enough.

Wanderer_03_7.speaker: Reagan Splint
Wanderer_03_7.text: With folk like you on the broadsheet front pages, it's hard to make the case against public execution. Scum.

Wanderer_03_8.speaker: Reagan Splint
Wanderer_03_8.text: If you're really one of those heroes like the Mouth says - you should reach out to them.

Wanderer_03_6.speaker: Reagan Splint
Wanderer_03_6.text: If we can get the gazette talking about the hangings - there can be some real change around here.

StreetGossiper_000_0.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
StreetGossiper_000_0.text: Look - I don't want your wares, I don't want to donate to anything, I'm just chatting with my friend. Excuse yourself.

StreetGossiper_000_1.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
StreetGossiper_000_1.text: Listen mate, I'm honoured, but ain't you got better things to do than chatter with me? You know, big heroics. Newsworthy stuff.

StreetGossiper_000_2.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
StreetGossiper_000_2.text: Can't believe Gortash's gone. Thought he was bloody invincible, way the broadsheets nattered on about him.

StreetGossiper_000_3.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
StreetGossiper_000_3.text: Well, well well. If it ain't the great hero the gazette's been harping on about. Look at you.

StreetGossiper_000_4.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
StreetGossiper_000_4.text: Sorry mate, trying to have a conflab here. No offence.

StreetGossiper_000_5.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
StreetGossiper_000_5.text: Oi, listen - oh. It's you. From the... uh, article. Ahem. I don't want any trouble, pal. Please.
StreetGossiper_000_5.context: NodeContext: nervous, he's heard how terrible you are

StreetGossiper_000_6.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
StreetGossiper_000_6.text: Come on, mate. I heard what you did in the gazette - I don't want anything to do with you.

StreetGossiper_000_7.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
StreetGossiper_000_7.text: Look mate, excuse yourself. Dead lords won't gossip about themselves.

PAD_PlayerLoadedPrinter_0.speaker: Player
PAD_PlayerLoadedPrinter_0.text: The editor will be in for a surprise tomorrow.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_0.speaker: Bunt Chugley
AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_0.text: Plenty of folk liked that Gortash bloke, judging by all the obituaries.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_1.speaker: Bunt Chugley
AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_1.text: Steer clear now, I don't want any of that trouble I read about.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_12.speaker: Bunt Chugley
AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_12.text: Just here for me walk. No trouble.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_2.speaker: Bunt Chugley
AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_2.text: Keep your distance Bunt, just here for walk. Don't engage.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_4.speaker: Bunt Chugley
AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_4.text: Can't believe Lord Gortash's shuffled off for good. S'all the gazette's printing these days.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_5.speaker: Bunt Chugley
AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_5.text: Never much time for lords, myself - but from what I read Gortash was a stand-up bloke.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_6.speaker: Bunt Chugley
AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_6.text: Hullo. Nice day for a - hang about. I read 'bout you.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_11.speaker: Bunt Chugley
AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_11.text: In the gazette - yeah. You're that rotter from the front page.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_7.speaker: Bunt Chugley
AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_7.text: Hullo. Nice day for a walk.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_9.speaker: Bunt Chugley
AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_9.text: Oh there you are, off on adventures no doubt.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_16.speaker: Bunt Chugley
AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_16.text: Look forward to reading 'bout them in the next edition.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_10.speaker: Bunt Chugley
AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_10.text: Hullo, nice day for - hang about. You're that hero-type from the gazette.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_3.speaker: Bunt Chugley
AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_3.text: Good stuff. Could do with more folk like you.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_15.speaker: Bunt Chugley
AD_ElfsongWanderer_001_15.text: Real nice things I read about you in the Mouth.

Worker_001_0.speaker: Zita
Worker_001_0.text: Between you and me - I don't even read 'em. Quality of reporting is arse these days.

Worker_001_1.speaker: Zita
Worker_001_1.text: Look, I just pack the papers. If you got a complaint - editor's inside.

AD_SkaraiBervos_1.speaker: Strange Beggar Lumbar
AD_SkaraiBervos_1.text: Oi, guv - I've more scoops for you.

Gossiper002_0.speaker: Carys
Gossiper002_0.text: Now, don't believe anything Cait over there tells you. She's an awful liar.

Gossiper002_1.speaker: Carys
Gossiper002_1.text: Don't get me wrong, I like a wee gossip as much as the rest, but Caitlin does get a bit carried away with the tall tales.

Gossiper002_2.speaker: Carys
Gossiper002_2.text: Say, I thought I recognised you from somewhere! Never seen the Mouth give such a glowing write-up. Good for you.

Gossiper002_3.speaker: Carys
Gossiper002_3.text: Keep your distance, now. I'll not consort with miscreants like you.

Reporter01_0.speaker: Salene Freig
Reporter01_0.text: Busy, busy, busy... Huh? You still standing there gawking? Shove off!

Reporter01_1.speaker: Salene Freig
Reporter01_1.text: Hey, cut it out, will you? I've got deliveries to manage.

AD_EttvardTaunt_0.speaker: Ettvard Needle
AD_EttvardTaunt_0.text: Watchers! The city's free speech is under threat - do your duty!

AD_EttvardTaunt_1.speaker: Ettvard Needle
AD_EttvardTaunt_1.text: Oh, you've just earned yourself a scathing obituary.

AD_StreetGossipers_14.speaker: Margolenn
AD_StreetGossipers_14.text: So, I was looking at the pictures in the gazette today...

AD_StreetGossipers_3.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
AD_StreetGossipers_3.text: Rather than reading the articles, yeah. You said.

AD_StreetGossipers_1.speaker: Margolenn
AD_StreetGossipers_1.text: Well, they were in the gazette. Saw their pictures and everything.

AD_StreetGossipers_13.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
AD_StreetGossipers_13.text: Oh, shit - you're right. The article about Absolutists... Bad news.

AD_StreetGossipers_8.speaker: Margolenn
AD_StreetGossipers_8.text: Yeah, they looked real mean in the broadsheet illustrations.

AD_StreetGossipers_10.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
AD_StreetGossipers_10.text: You're right - apparently they're these hero types.

AD_StreetGossipers_5.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
AD_StreetGossipers_5.text: I don't think they were in the gazette, mate. This is why you've got to read it.

AD_StreetGossipers_4.speaker: Margolenn
AD_StreetGossipers_4.text: Yeah, this edition looked better than ever!

AD_StreetGossipers_0.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
AD_StreetGossipers_0.text: ...What do you mean better than ever? It was all about Lord Gortash dying!

AD_StreetGossipers_6.speaker: Margolenn
AD_StreetGossipers_6.text: Oh, right. Nah, I don't read any of the gazette. I like the pictures, me.

AD_StreetGossipers_2.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
AD_StreetGossipers_2.text: But how do you stay informed about stuff? Dying lords, new wars, anything?

AD_StreetGossipers_9.speaker: Margolenn
AD_StreetGossipers_9.text: I don't. Don't see the point - staying informed seems super stressful.

AD_StreetGossipers_12.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
AD_StreetGossipers_12.text: Hearing you say that stresses me out more than the gazette, mate.

AD_StreetGossipers_7.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
AD_StreetGossipers_7.text: Wait, if you don't read the gazette, how do you stay informed?!

AD_StreetGossipers_11.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
AD_StreetGossipers_11.text: ...Better than ever? With all the articles about cults and war?

AD_StreetGossipers_16.speaker: 'Bigmouth' Thimsen
AD_StreetGossipers_16.text: Read the gazette today yet, mate?

AD_Cynics_1.speaker: Sharlz Molar
AD_Cynics_1.text: Gazette has a transcript of a conversation with Archduke Gortash.

AD_Cynics_16.speaker: Iza Blouin
AD_Cynics_16.text: What's he got to say for himself?

AD_Cynics_4.speaker: Sharlz Molar
AD_Cynics_4.text: Lots of talk about the brilliant future of Baldur's Gate, city of steel and justice.

AD_Cynics_15.speaker: Iza Blouin
AD_Cynics_15.text: Does he say anything about the horrible present of Baldur's Gate, city of crime and chaos?

AD_Cynics_5.speaker: Sharlz Molar
AD_Cynics_5.text: No. He mostly avoids that topic.

AD_Cynics_2.speaker: Iza Blouin
AD_Cynics_2.text: Huh. Now that's something you don't see in the Mouth every day.

AD_Cynics_14.speaker: Sharlz Molar
AD_Cynics_14.text: What's in this edition? More Absolute scaremongering?

AD_Cynics_11.speaker: Iza Blouin
AD_Cynics_11.text: A positive headline. About a group of adventurers, no less.

AD_Cynics_7.speaker: Sharlz Molar
AD_Cynics_7.text: Adventurers, necromancers, cults... Where's the reporting on real things?

AD_Cynics_3.speaker: Sharlz Molar
AD_Cynics_3.text: How do 'adventurers' help us normal folk? Not one bloody bit, that's how.

AD_Cynics_12.speaker: Iza Blouin
AD_Cynics_12.text: Gods, you'd think the late Lord Gortash was a saint the way the Gazette goes on about him.

AD_Cynics_17.speaker: Sharlz Molar
AD_Cynics_17.text: Yeah, they've really made a meal out of the 'Death of Gortash' stuff.

AD_Cynics_10.speaker: Iza Blouin
AD_Cynics_10.text: Won't tell us how Gortash died though, will they? Classic Baldur's Mouth.

AD_Cynics_18.speaker: Iza Blouin
AD_Cynics_18.text: 'Adventurers aid Absolute'... Reckon there's any truth to that?

AD_Cynics_0.speaker: Sharlz Molar
AD_Cynics_0.text: Truth? In the Baldur's Mouth Gazette?

AD_Cynics_13.speaker: Iza Blouin
AD_Cynics_13.text: The Gazette can't be wrong all the time.

AD_Cynics_19.speaker: Iza Blouin
AD_Cynics_19.text: Adventurers are basically mercenaries. Stands to reason some of them would side with a mad cult if it paid well enough.

AD_Cynics_6.speaker: Sharlz Molar
AD_Cynics_6.text: What difference does it make? Cults come and go, and so do adventurers.

AD_Cynics_8.speaker: Sharlz Molar
AD_Cynics_8.text: The Gazette never prints anything that'll affect us regular folk. S'all a distraction.

PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_0.speaker: News Hawker Chalara
PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_0.text: My mum said if you can't play nicely, don't play at all. You've not been very nice.

PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_2.speaker: News Hawker Chalara
PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_2.text: Whoa, I know you - you're in the gazette today! Saying you're a proper hero-sort!

PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_21.speaker: News Hawker Chalara
PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_21.text: If you want to read about it, you'll have to buy a copy. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_24.speaker: News Hawker Chalara
PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_24.text: If you change your mind you know where to find me!

PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_13.speaker: News Hawker Chalara
PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_13.text: Nice to see youse again! Today's edition's cheap, if you fancy it. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_20.speaker: News Hawker Chalara
PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_20.text: Good day, guv'nor, I gots a copy of the Bladder's Mouth Gazette fresh off the presses for you - good price, too! ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_11.speaker: Player
PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_11.text: I'll take a copy of the Gazette. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_26.speaker: News Hawker Chalara
PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_26.text: Cor, thanks! Come back tomorrow for the next edition.

PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_8.speaker: News Hawker Chalara
PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_8.text: Oh piss... I mean the Baldur's Mouth Gazette, sorry! Please don't tell Mister Ettvard, he'd be ever so cross.

PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_10.speaker: News Hawker Chalara
PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_10.text: Not to worry, there's a new edition every day!

PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_23.speaker: News Hawker Chalara
PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_23.text: Get your Gazette here! Only... Oh. Oh no. You're that nasty person from today's edition -

PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_4.speaker: Player
PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_4.text: Calm down. I'm just buying a paper. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_16.speaker: News Hawker Chalara
PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_16.text: AHH! Okayokayokay, just take one and leave me alone!

PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_15.speaker: News Hawker Chalara
PaperBoy_SteepsStrake_15.text: N... No. Mister Ettvard said to be m-more assertive. Go away, meanie!

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_1.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_1.text: You're exactly the sort Lord Gortash was talking about in his interview.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_4.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_4.text: In fact, I bet Gortash mentions you scum next time he's interviewed.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_2.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_2.text: I look forward to reading about your next exploits!

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_5.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_5.text: Watch yourself - hang on, I know you.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_0.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_0.text: I read about you! In the Gazette! Ooh, you're a PROPER wrong'un.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_8.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_8.text: You seen any Gazetteers around? Need to see if the new edition's out yet.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_9.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_9.text: I know that face - you're the one from the gazette!

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_3.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_3.text: A real hero... thought you'd be taller, though.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_10.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_10.text: Only last tenday Gortash was being interviewed, now the Mouth's printing his obituary.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_11.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_11.text: You should see if the Baldur's Mouth will interview you.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_15.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_15.text: The Gazette loves interviewing heroes, they talked to Gortash last tenday.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_13.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_13.text: Careful, CAREFUL! People don't bloody look where they're walking.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_6.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_6.text: The gazette's right - folk these days have no manners.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_14.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_14.text: You hear about Lord Gortash? It's all over the broadsheets.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_18.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_18.text: Shame... Apparently he was a good man, for a lord.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_16.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_16.text: Here's a tip - latest Baldur's Mouth edition? Dynamite. That Lord Gortash...

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_7.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_7.text: Should have his own column, never mind just an interview.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_17.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_17.text: Nothing but doom and gloom in the Gazette since Gortash died.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_19.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_19.text: Didn't the guards read the Baldur's Mouth? You should be booted from the city.

AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_12.speaker: Cressida Flint
AD_ElfsongWanderer_000_12.text: Hang on, can the guards even read?

StreetGossiper_001_1.speaker: Margolenn
StreetGossiper_001_1.text: If you like pictures, the gazette's got some brilliant illustrators. Really pops off the page.

StreetGossiper_001_2.speaker: Margolenn
StreetGossiper_001_2.text: Now, I didn't read the article, but apparently it said you were a real piece of work... so I'll have nothing to do with you.

StreetGossiper_001_3.speaker: Margolenn
StreetGossiper_001_3.text: The gazette's illustrations have been magic since Gortash died - proper evocative. Guess grief does that to folks.

StreetGossiper_001_4.speaker: Margolenn
StreetGossiper_001_4.text: Wow, it's you! From the gazette! You look even more heroical in real life!

StreetGossiper_001_0.speaker: Margolenn
StreetGossiper_001_0.text: Especially since they announced Lord Gortash's death. So many illustrations.

StreetGossiper_001_6.speaker: Margolenn
StreetGossiper_001_6.text: Oh - I saw your picture in the gazette. Very accurate... Captured that mean look in your eyes.

StreetGossiper_001_7.speaker: Margolenn
StreetGossiper_001_7.text: Normally the Baldur's Mouth illustrators capture people perfectly - but they didn't do you justice. Wow.

StreetGossiper_001_8.speaker: Margolenn
StreetGossiper_001_8.text: Can you believe how good the latest issue of the Baldur's Mouth looked? Me neither. Great broadsheet.

EttvardsReplacement_DefaultDialog_0.speaker: Syril Valdemar
EttvardsReplacement_DefaultDialog_0.text: No time for chit-chat, I'm afraid. Lord Gortash may be dead, but the news lives on!

EttvardsReplacement_DefaultDialog_1.speaker: Syril Valdemar
EttvardsReplacement_DefaultDialog_1.text: I've no time for idle chatter - the news doesn't sleep, especially in such dangerous times.

EttvardsReplacement_DefaultDialog_2.speaker: Syril Valdemar
EttvardsReplacement_DefaultDialog_2.text: They tried to silence us, but as long as the city breathes, the Mouth will speak!

EttvardsReplacement_DefaultDialog_3.speaker: Syril Valdemar
EttvardsReplacement_DefaultDialog_3.text: Even if you've nothing better to do, I'm afraid I have. It's not every day a lord drops dead!

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_0.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_0.text: If those metal brutes actually did their jobs, you'd be off the street.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_5.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_5.text: Guess the Steel Watch isn't as effective as the Mouth claims.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_1.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_1.text: Here's hoping those clanking Watchers go the same way as Gortash.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_2.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_2.text: If Gortash was so clever, how'd he end up dead? Don't see the Mouth asking that.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_3.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_3.text: Should try and get yourself a proper interview in the gazette.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_17.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_17.text: Tell them the Steel Watch isn't needed anymore.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_6.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_6.text: Read all about you, villain. City will need even more Steel Watchers with folks like you causing havoc.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_8.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_8.text: Hoped the foundry would pack up now Gortash's done for. No such luck.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_9.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_9.text: And those clanking great Steel Watchers?

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_7.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_7.text: Bloody hate them, no matter what the Mouth says.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_11.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_11.text: Oi, you're that heroic type from the latest Baldur's Mouth edition.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_4.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_4.text: Nice reading about something positive for once.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_12.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_12.text: Personally, I don't see why we need the Steel Watch.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_16.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_16.text: With folks like you cutting about our streets, we're safe as can be.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_15.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_15.text: The gazette reckons Lord Gortash is the second coming of Balduran. Horsecack.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_18.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_18.text: Breeze must be blowing inland today. Bringing in the stench of the foundry.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_13.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_13.text: Belching smoke and metal screeches... 'Keep the city peaceful' my arse.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_19.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_19.text: Come on, scum, sling your hook already.

AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_14.speaker: Wynn Freshwater
AD_Wanderer_08_Greeting_14.text: Don't agree with the Baldur's Mouth on much, but you need to leave.
